metadata.name: Bastard Anonymous #2
metadata.description: This is an Anonymous Bastard, savior of heaven and earth, god on earth. He wants to dominate but spends his time watching Cartoon Network.

metadata.name: Monotipia #73
metadata.description:
Graphic compositions made with simple elements. Playing with the subtlety and rhythm of colors, shapes and textures.

This work was inspired by the textures of monotype prints and those of metal engraving. Especially in the geometric marks made by the inking roller while stretching the graphic ink to make a manual printing. It is a tribute to the visuality of handmade prints.

"Monotipia" means monotype printing in Portuguese. It is a graphic printing process that results in a single copy. Here I make a parallel between monotype printing and the code+hash minting process, which also produces a single image.

---
Features:
-> 15 composition schemes
-> 51 handpicked base colors
-> 3 canvas formats:  
-----> Portrait (vertical) 
-----> Square 
-----> Landscape (horizontal)
-> 3 element tones options: 
-----> Light Texture & Shapes
-----> Light Texture / Dark Shapes 
-----> Dark Texture & Shapes

---
To save the image as a png file, type:
[1] save at actual size 
[2] save with 2000px height
[3] save with 3000px height
[4] save with 4000px height
[5] save with 5000px height

Depending on the size option, the render time can be long.

---
Created with p5.js

---
This is my first project on FX(hash) and I would like to express my special thanks to Janaina Selva, Dmarchi, Gyo and Morbeck for their support and for following the step-by-step development of this work, always contributing with a critical eye and great suggestions. I also thank the help from the FX(hash) community on Discord.

---
(c) Marcelo Ter√ßa-Nada, 2023
https://marcelonada.redezero.org/
@marcelonada

metadata.name: CA Vista #234
metadata.description:
Stephen Wolfram's cellular automata and Perlin noise come together to generate landscapes.

Press 'S' to download.

metadata.name: Threadbare #86
metadata.description:
Threadbare is a generative art project that explores the beauty that can be found in the everyday wear and tear of textiles. Through the modeling of fabrics and how they respond to being ripped, frayed, and holed, Threadbare creates a representation of the passage of time and the gradual transformation of materials. This project is part of a study by the artist to use generative art to model natural processes and materials.

- You can press [1-9] to resize at multiples of 800 (i.e. 1 = 800x800, 3 = 2400x2400).

- Press [d] to download as a png at anytime.

Created using p5.js

metadata.name: kari #198
metadata.description:
Structures in construction.

Press 's' in full screen mode to save a 1280x2024 version.
Press 'h' in full screen mode to save a 2560x4096 version.

metadata.name: Dreamcatcher Forest #665
metadata.description:
"Dreamcatcher Forest" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Art Basel, Basel 2022. The illustration in this work draws inspiration from Native American dreamcatchers, a protective talisman crafted from beautifully intricate patterns of woven thread, built from natural materials & colorful beads.

Dreamcatchers are used to protect dreamers while they sleep. Good dreams are able to slip through the web to meet the sleeper beneath, while bad dreams are trapped and prevented.

- Use the "S" key to save a PNG image.
- Use the "P" key to export a print-quality image.

metadata.name: Hyperspacers #22
metadata.description:
Ancient creatures from deep space who can travel infinite great distances in hyperspace in an instant. They bring the seeds of life to remote corners of various galaxies.

This drawing is created with many thousands of strokes using pure javascript.

metadata.name: Fibril #123
metadata.description:
real-time webGL fabric simulation. 

p - play/pause
r - reset to initial state
s - export plottable svg
i - zoom in
o - zoom out

WebGL 2.0 support required.

metadata.name: Florescence #276
metadata.description:
Digitally crafted flowers in pots for virtual window sills.

In the spirit of the piranha plant from the Mario Bros videogame. We wanted to create a project that acknowledges the playful depiction of nature in early videogames by creating a retro futuristic collectible that explores aesthetics over gameplay, whilst preserving the playful energy of these early digital worlds. There are many game elements that have emerged over the years that have become iconic in their own right. Their memorable designs have come to represent the exciting feeling of when we first discovered these worlds, but over time an appreciation for their simple design execution, harmony and balance has emerged. Art can exist in many forms and places including a digital pot plant.

Rarity:

There are a total of 23 hand-drawn and animated sprites divided into 4 groups Firelillies, Flytraps, Quasars and Stargazers and there are 15 possible combinations made from these 4 groups. 18% of the collection is a combination of these 4 groups which we can call random and the remaining 72% is divided between the remaining 14 combinations.


There are 3 possible grid systems 1x1, 3x3 and 4x4 

3% 1x1

40% 3x3

57% 4x4



There are 14 possible placement points for all grids and 76 stem/sprite arragement in total



For the pots and stems there are 11 colors to choose and  no rarities for color combinations.



The flower distribution can be either symmetric or random. 35% symmetric and 65% random



Export options:

Pressing 's' on desktop or holding for 2 seconds will download gif to whatever the current device resolution is. To export at a different resolution open the token in new window by clicking 'open' link under the token image and add "&exportsize=1080" or "&exportsize=2160" to end of the url and hit enter then either hold for 2 seconds or press 's' to create gif and download.

metadata.name: Ethereal Microcosm #243
metadata.description:
An exploration of algorithmic organisms in a contained environment.

This piece is about the simulation of microscopic patterns using a high number of even tinier agents all following the same rules. Different species evolve and interact together, resulting in stabilizing patterns out of their parametric configurations. A form of artificial life.

This work is based on the paper "Characteristics of pattern formation and evolution in approximations of physarum transport networks", written by Jeff Jones and popularized in the artistic field by Sage Jenson. Some features were added to increase the visual and behavioral complexity of the system. Agents are divided into different species, with their own set of rules and interacting with their own substrate. Substrates also interact with each other and agents will mutate in contact of some of them.

NFT License
Runs properly on Chrome 97.0.4692.99
GPU intensive

Press P to pause (double tab touch devices)
Press

metadata.name: Representation #58
metadata.description:
Explore the world of gender politics through vibrant circles.

Representation is an artwork/data visualization about the gender split in parliaments across the world. 

Each minted artwork gets assigned 6 countries from different regions. 1 country from the Pacific, 1 from Europe, 1 from Asia, 1 from the Americas, 1 from Sub-saharan Africa and 1 from the Middle East and North Africa.

Each circle in your artwork represents the gender split of the parliament(s) in one of those countries by using colors. The legend in the bottom right can be used to decipher which color means what.

This artwork was created using p5js.

The artwork adapts to different screen sizes and ratios, so I exploring it on various devices or resizing your browser window. 

Features:

- Circle Size: What size are the circles?
- Circle Distance: How far apart from each other are the circles?
- Circle Scatter: Are the circles scattered on the Y-axis?

twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art

metadata.name: Hypericum #156
metadata.description:
This system translates color into movement. A swarm of drawing particles, like virtual pencils, are guided by the color values of the pixels in an input image. The formulas performing the conversion put into play many parameters. The space of possibilities of the system is enormous, the variety of drawings endless. 256 is just a small arbitrary sample. 

This work can be seen as a playful reflection on the concept of ‚Äústyle‚Äù, which is so essential to our ideas about art and (human) artists. This short program can paint the same image on infinitely many ‚Äústyles‚Äù ‚Äì each of them reducible to a simple combination of mathematical parameters. 

The input image is a photo of a yellow hypericum flower I took during a holiday in the Argentinean Patagonia, near Bariloche, in 2016.

Better on landscape format (optimal ratio is 3:2) > on your computer, [open live]
Press [s] to download capture.

Made by Leonardo Solaas
TW > @solaas
IG > @leonardo_solaas
WWW > solaas.com.ar

"s" to save export.

metadata.name: Bardez #293
metadata.description:
Bardez is the Armenian word for garden. It is etymologically tied to an ancient word for paradise, but that link goes deeper than etymology. Gardens have always been small pieces of paradise for me, and hearing the word in Armenian triggers a flood of warm memories.

Memories of wandering around my grandfather‚Äôs garden, plucking ripe plums and figs from their branches.
Memories of playing in my parents yard, the scent of jasmine in the summer heat.
Of sun warmed tomatoes in my mom‚Äôs vegetable patch.
The smell of dirt and grass.
Mud on my hands.
Sun on my skin.
Memories of paradise.

I hope you enjoy these gardens I‚Äôve planted, and I hope they remind you of some warm and wonderful memories.
 
Nat Sarkissian






Notes:
 - This piece uses a shader to compute the lighting of the terrain in the first frame. If you don‚Äôt have a graphics card, you may have difficulty running this.

 - Append ‚Äú&mag=N‚Äù to the end of the URL in live mode to specify a resolution multiplier. It will render the image N times larger than the size of your window. If you have specified anything greater than 1, a download will start automatically once the rendering is done. The maximum resolution seems to be limited by what your web browser allows. I have been able to output up to 11140px tall and wide using Firefox, which should be enough detail for prints up to 37x37 inches. I recommend keeping the console open while attempting larger renders. It will show you the progress of the render, and also show you if you have attempted too large a render for your system. N can be any positive whole or decimal number greater than or equal to 1.

 - Finally, collectors at the highest tier will be entitled to a signed print of their edition. For further details and updates, keep an eye on my Twitter (@_NatSarkissian).
